Comment: Nice clash, good level of difficulty, good test cases.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

What is the expected output for test case:
10 1000
11 100
Is it "No Same Pay"?

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Some light and accessible math, lgtm!

Had to re-read a few times, please place commas in the description:
"Alice earns a flat fee of {{a}} dollars, plus {{b}} dollars per hour"

Otherwise, classic maths problem, should be accessible to most :)

(and also amazed by the fact 5DN1L is still reviewing new clashes of code after all of this time)

Nice clash, only issue is that there's so many test cases imo.

It's not so bad in itself, but in Fastest mode when there's this many tests it's really easy to hit submit when you see most of them are Green and end up losing because you missed an edge case that's covered in a later test.

"No Same Pay Again Again" is probably the edge case most likely to catch people out, since you have to take care for the situation where the hourly fees are equal. It being the 13th test means it's pretty likely that some clashers are going to hit submit without realising they didn't code for this edge case.

I'd recommend moving it earlier or just reducing the number of tests to 10 or less.

Output
* Please change "with" to "for the hours worked and dollars earned, rounded to".

("With" is not specific enough: is it round, round up, round down or truncate? That's why it should be changed to "rounded to" in the current clash.)

* Should you mention that flat fees are not paid if no work is done? For example, if that wasn't the case, and if a = c and b â‰  d, then the answer would be "[[a]] [[0.00]]" instead of "No Same Pay".

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Cases
* No Same Pay.1 (validator): Please revise the case such that a > c and b > d.

* Please add a pair of cases where a < c and b < d and a, b, c, d are all floats.

* Please add a pair of cases where a = c and b > d and a, b, c, d are all floats.

* Please add a pair of cases where a = c and b < d and a, b, c, d are all floats.

* Please add a pair of cases where a > c and b = d and a, b, c, d are all floats.

* Please add a pair of cases where a < c and b = d and a, b, c, d are all floats.

* Please add a pair of cases where a â‰  c and b â‰  d and a, b, c, d are all floats and the output figures are both greater than 10.

Thanks.
Done
The first five pairs of cases can be reduced to one pair.
ok thx
Answer should be 0.01 11.11

It turns out there's a bit of an issue with this clash in Shortest mode for Ruby. I got 90% after getting 100% on tests.

If you just evaluate the inputs e.g. eval"A,B,C,D="+`tr '
 ' ,`
Then you can end up doing integer division to find the number of hours before parity
h=-(A-C)/(B-D)

This works fine in Test 1 (Graduate):
h=-(-15)/(5)=3 {integer division is correct}
But fails for Validator 1 (Graduate.1(:
h=(-17)/(5)=3 {integer division fails, h=3.4}

Graduate.1 is the only test/validator that causes any problems like this.
It would be good to either add a test that has this issue too, or make it so all inputs have ".0" after them if they are integers, so that 'eval' approaches will not assume integers at all.
The answer is rounded to 2  decimal places

Could you please explain math behind this specific example?
In order to get 11.11 
Alice should work for 1.11/1000 = 0.00111 hours
Bob should work for 0.11/100 = 0.0011 hours

By rounding this number we should get 0.00 hours
This looks a bit confusing
Usually floating points plays poorly with currency. Is it the point for this problem?
I see your point
Ok i changed my solution to make this work
What is the expected result for this case?
Should we update description to clarify this corner case?
How would you word this?

Note:
After rounding following equation may not hold
flat fee + dollars per hour * time = salary
Thanks
ok

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Goal / Cases
* tl;dr: Please delete "Note: Flat fees are not paid if no work is done." For context, read the explanation below.

Thanks!

------------------

Explanation:

If the correct output for "Easy Money" and "More Easy Money" (test/validator) is 0 hours and the corresponding fixed fee, then the note (flat fees are not paid if no work is done) doesn't hold.

My original intention was that if the number of hours = 0, then the fixed fee wouldn't be paid either. This implied that some work had to be done to receive any payment. Given that the fixed fees are identical and only the hourly rates differ, this would mean they could never receive the same total pay â€” and thus the answer would be "No Same Pay".

However, there's a valid counterpoint that "0.00 0.00" could be considered a legitimate solution. On reflection, your current treatment might actually be the better approach.
